body:
p.s this is not an official post

Hey boys, ready?

The whole procedure of the ban was messy. I wasn't there that night Zaoki got screenshared, so LFT didn't know if what he found was an autoclicker or not. It turned out it pretty much was, however we couldn't 100% confirm he was autoclicking, as only an autoclicker was found. This however, was defined as a punishable offence in the ruleset, whether we could prove he was using it or not. His autoclicker also matched up with the many alerts he set off in 1 match x)

Therefore, officials were unsure of what to do as PureDogs had got in their heads and they were unsure whether what had been found was an autoclicker. This was because the officials were still waiting for my confirmation on what was found, so PureDogs had time to type and make up explanations.

Nothing was being done after a few days, Zaoki was unable to go on his computer to attempt to prove himself. 

Kyoal then decided with Posighdun it would be a good idea to create a vote. This vote was an experiment for the officials, by Kyoal. He likes to impress Posighdun. Kyoal instantly voted for no dq, pressuring other officials to do so as they want to make what seems to be the right decision.  Then I woke up and they were getting disqualified whatever I voted.

Kyoal thought it would be a good decision to make an experiment on the officials, when he was one of the only ones stopping a dq from happening earlier that week.  And still to this moment, some officials are not aware of the vote being an experiment by kyoal.

After the decision was public, and it had been announced, there was (rightfully so) a shit storm created by the community.  This lead to officials who voted for no dq either feeling 1 of 2 things: 
  • realising the decision they made
  • wanting to change their decision, although it was too late, because of the shitstorm created
This made everyone realise we as a team messed up, causing everyone to post why they voted for no dq publically. Most people did, Kyoal didn't however, and was refusing to even tell the official team.

Hope this clears shit up

*ps* LFT was the ONLY official to vote for a DQ.

Tazz (not offiicials)

replies.body:
Why did only 1 person vote for a DQ? It makes no sense.

Although you can't fully justify the autoclicker, Zaoki is still banned. Therefore, the right action to take was to disqualify/blacklist the rest of the team, this is quite an obvious rule and I have seen it been used before.

Yet for some reason you decided to go against your own rule. Yeah you admit you fucked up, well ban them now, and take away their position as champions is what I say. Why can't you do it now? There's no reason you can't. 

Also, I still request a logical explanation as to why NewDawn were disqualified and moved outside of the top 8 when we were clearly 8th, yet somehow HeartClaw got through. Please, someone explain this to me, this doesn't make sense because we no-showed only 1 game. Thank you.

replies.body:
The vote was called because it took 5 days to even talk about it and no decision had been reached so I called a vote, as I thought they would all vote for DQ as it made sense to dq them.  I only found out about Kyoals experiment during the semi finals and it was already too late to do anything at that point.

 Kyoal did make a mistake but we all make mistakes at some point, and that's probably one questionable thing he has done amongst 1000 good things. He is very passionate about this community and never meant for it to get out of hand like it did. I'm not condoning what he did, as he should not have done it but like I said it's already too late so we'll just have to learn from our mistakes.

replies.body:
I probably have no right in posting since I am not aware of the situation but I am basing this response off the original post...

Seriously, what's the big fuss about? If this guy is hacking, god damn ban him. I don't see why a vote was needed, or anyone else needed to be involved. If a senior moderator witnesses a player breaking the rules wouldn't it be plausible if he immediately punished? I mean, that's independence... right? Right?

In fact, almost every decision the officials seem to make is either revoked or heavily dramatized. Is it the influence of the administrators or is it the constant pressure of appealing to the majority? I don't know, but as Snow stated, I am having difficulties in finding an individual who is a prime leader in the official team. Actually, there shouldn't be, but instead the administrators need to be taking charge of most operations in the tournament team. There is no guidance - and therefore there is an absolute break down on one of the most fundamental business models. Why are the two teams acting seperate - pointing fingers?

That makes no sense.
If we put [Tournament] in an infraction, it means that infraction only applies to Tournaments.

In the same way that we (used to?) put [Forum] on a forum-related infraction. i.e Forum warns 
That only applied to the forums.

We don't specify where we found the infraction, we only specify which areas the infraction is valid.
